importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on October 9, 2025, setting the timeline for the return of deceased hostages and the implementation of the agreement between Israel and Hamas.
On October 21, 2025, two coffins containing the apparent remains of deceased hostages were transferred into Israel, marking the 14th and 15th bodies returned under the ceasefire agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Under the Trump administration’s ceasefire agreement, Hamas was required to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours of the ceasefire going into effect.

keyTakeAways: The Israeli military confirmed that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred into Israel from Gaza, escorted by IDF troops.
The bodies are being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, with all 13 previously identified bodies confirmed as part of the agreement.
Hamas has acknowledged the transfer of the two new bodies as scheduled, though one prior body was misidentified—indicating potential challenges in recovery and identification efforts.
Israeli intelligence believes Hamas may not be able to locate and return all remaining dead hostages due to rubble and difficult conditions in Gaza.
US Vice President JD Vance emphasized that the return of bodies is a priority, but acknowledged it is not happening overnight, noting some bodies are buried under rubble.
The transfer of these two coffins occurred after US officials, including Vance, arrived in Israel to oversee the next phase of the ceasefire plan.
Hamas and Israel accused each other of ceasefire violations, contributing to the fragile nature of the agreement and delays in the return of hostages.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation in the Middle East, central to the geopolitical conflict described in the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is the primary party involved in the conflict, and the return of hostages is a central policy objective for its government and military.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant organization and political entity that controls parts of Gaza and is in conflict with Israel.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the opposing party in the conflict and is responsible for the custody and transfer of the deceased hostages under the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The armed wing of Hamas, responsible for military operations and enforcement of Hamas policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Al-Qassam Brigades confirmed the scheduled transfer of the two coffins, indicating active involvement in the hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military branch of the Israeli government, responsible for national defense and security operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF escorted the coffins and confirmed the transfer, playing a key role in both security and the handling of the remains.

namedEntities.name: Israel Security Agency (ISA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key intelligence and security body within Israel, responsible for internal security and intelligence operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ISA jointly issued a statement with the IDF confirming the arrival of the coffins and their transfer to forensic authorities.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution responsible for forensic investigations and body identification.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The institute is where the identification of the two new bodies will take place, a critical step in confirming the identities and causes of death.

namedEntities.name: Ministry of Health (Israel)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A government department responsible for public health and medical services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ministry confirmed the arrival of the bodies at the forensic institute and acknowledged ongoing identification efforts.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government led by former President Donald Trump, responsible for diplomatic initiatives in the region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The administration proposed and supported the ceasefire deal, which set the framework for hostage returns and ceasefire compliance.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. Vice President, who visited Israel to oversee the implementation of the ceasefire agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance publicly addressed concerns about the return of bodies, downplayed fragility, and emphasized the difficulty of the task.

namedEntities.name: Sergeant Major Tal Haimi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli military personnel, identified as one of the deceased hostages returned under the agreement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His identification marks the 13th confirmed body returned, showing the process of identification and accountability under the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global power involved in mediating the ceasefire through diplomatic efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The U.S. proposed and backed the ceasefire deal, making it a key player in the international response to the hostage crisis.

namedEntities.name: Red Cross
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international humanitarian organization involved in the care of the wounded and dead in conflict zones.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Red Cross handed over the coffins to Israeli forces, indicating their role in the formal transfer of the deceased.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Israeli military reported that two coffins containing the remains of deceased Israeli hostages were transferred into Israel from Gaza, escorted by Israeli Defense Forces and the Israel Security Agency. These bodies are now being processed at the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification, marking the 14th and 15th confirmed deceased hostages returned since the ceasefire agreement signed on October 9, 2025. Hamas confirmed the transfer, though one previous body was misidentified, highlighting challenges in recovery due to rubble and difficult access. Israeli intelligence believes Hamas may not be able to recover all remaining bodies. US Vice President JD Vance emphasized that returning the bodies is a priority, acknowledging the difficulty and that it will not happen overnight. The transfer occurred during a period of heightened tension, with both sides accusing each other of ceasefire violations, and signals ongoing challenges in implementing the ceasefire agreement.
title: Israeli Military Says Two Coffins Said to Contain Hostages' Bodies Cross Into Israel
